keyTakeAways: David Hockney's iPad drawings of the Yorkshire Wolds were sold at Sotheby's for £6.2 million.
The 17 drawings, titled 'The Arrival of Spring in Woldgate', were created between 2011 and 2012, following his move from Beverly Hills to Bridlington.
This collection represents the largest group of Hockney's iPad drawings to come to market, making it a rare and significant sale event.
The drawings were inspired by Hockney's daily visits to Woldgate and his realization that traditional plein air painting was impractical in winter conditions.
The sale coincided with the Frieze art fair, adding to its visibility and cultural relevance in the art world.
The works were originally exhibited at the Royal Academy of Arts in 2012, indicating their importance in art history and public exhibitions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: David Hockney's 17 iPad drawings titled 'The Arrival of Spring in Woldgate' were sold at Sotheby's for £6.2 million, making it the largest group of his iPad drawings to come to market. Created between 2011 and 2012, the series emerged after Hockney moved to Bridlington, Yorkshire, and began drawing daily in the Yorkshire Wolds. Inspired by his personal connections to the region—rooted in childhood summers in East Yorkshire and visits to see his mother and friend Jonathan Silver—the work reflects both artistic innovation and deep emotional ties. The drawings were first exhibited at the Royal Academy of Arts in 2012 and were sold during the Frieze art fair, emphasizing their cultural and commercial significance.
